title: Customise output from excelerate
text: Use excelerate demonstrated Get Started:
code: library(excelerate)  # Set up temporary directory to save the excel spreadsheets in temp_dir <- tempdir()  # Load example datasets datasets <- list(iris, ChickWeight, ToothGrowth, CO2)  iris_commented <- append_meta(   results = iris,   colname_descriptions = c(     "Sepal.Length" = "Length of the sepal in cm",     "Sepal.Width" = "Width of the sepal in cm",     "Petal.Length" = "Length of the petal in cm",     "Petal.Width" = "Width of the petal in cm",     "Species" = "Species of iris"   ) )  chickweight_commented <- append_meta(   results = ChickWeight,   colname_descriptions = c(     "weight" = "Weight of the chick in grams",     "Time" = "Time in days",     "Chick" = "Chick identifier",     "Diet" = "Diet type"   ) )  toothgrowth_commented <- append_meta(   results = ToothGrowth,   colname_descriptions = c(     "len" = "Tooth length in mm",     "supp" = "Supplement type (VC or OJ)",     "dose" = "Dose of the supplement in mg"   ) ) co2_commented <- append_meta(   results = CO2,   colname_descriptions = c(     "Plant" = "Identifier for the plant",     "Type" = "Type of plant (Quebec or Mississippi)",     "Treatment" = "Treatment type (nonchilled or chilled)",     "conc" = "Concentration of CO2 in uL/L",     "uptake" = "CO2 uptake in mg"   ) )  supplementary_table_1 <- spreadsheet(   title = "Results for iris and ChickWeight. 'title' from spreadsheet().",   path = file.path(temp_dir),   file = "",   sheet(     iris_commented,     "iris sheet_name",     "sheet_legend for the iris dataset."   ),   sheet(     chickweight_commented,     "ChickWeight sheet_name",     "sheet_legend for the ChickWeight dataset."   ) )  supplementary_table_2 <- spreadsheet(   title = "Results for toothgrowth and C02 R supplied datasets.",   path = file.path(temp_dir),   file = "",   sheet(     toothgrowth_commented,     "ToothGrowth sheet_name",     "sheet_legend for the ToothGrowth dataset."   ),   sheet(     co2_commented,     "CO2 sheet_name",     "sheet_legend for the CO2 dataset."   ) )  # Save supplementary tables as .xlsx to temp_dir excelerate(   supplementary_table_1,   supplementary_table_2 ) #> Excel file saved successfuly at: /tmp/RtmpSQIxHh/S1.xlsx #> Excel file saved successfuly at: /tmp/RtmpSQIxHh/S2.xlsx  # Check files were made successfully list.files(temp_dir, pattern = "\\.xlsx$", full.names = TRUE) #> [1] "/tmp/RtmpSQIxHh/S1.xlsx" "/tmp/RtmpSQIxHh/S2.xlsx"

title: Customise output from excelerate
text: example make cells row bold column “Petal.Width” < 0.3, iris dataset. iris data inserted “S1.xlsx” code chunk, sheet name “iris sheet_name”. Remember sheet names automatically default prefixed “A1”, “B1” etc. ’s Supplementary Table 1, “A2”, “B2” etc. ’s Supplementary Table 2. article demonstration use output excelerate() customise supplementary tables . details see openxlsx R package write functions customise tables.
code: # Create custom function to bold rows based on a certain condition # using the openxlsx R package library(openxlsx)  # ------- WRITE FUNCTION ----------------- # Write a function to style rows and resave Excel files style_rows <- function(data, wb, row_indices,                        style_type, path_file, sheet_name) {   # Create a style   style <- openxlsx::createStyle(textDecoration = "bold")    # Apply style to all columns in the selected rows   openxlsx::addStyle(     wb,     sheet = sheet_name,     style = style,     rows = row_indices_to_style + 1, # +1 because first row is the header     cols = seq_len(ncol(data)),     gridExpand = TRUE   )    # Resave Excel file   saveWorkbook(wb, file = path_file, overwrite = TRUE) }  # ------- USE FUNCTIONS ------------------ # Read in S1.xlsx, the file generated by excelerate(), with the iris sheet wb <- openxlsx::loadWorkbook(file.path(temp_dir, "S1.xlsx"))  iris_data <- openxlsx::read.xlsx(wb, sheet = "1A iris sheet_name")  # Get the index of the rows that we want to make bold row_indices_to_style <- which(iris_data$Petal.Width < 0.3)  # Make the rows bold and resave the Excel file style_rows(   iris_data,   wb,   row_indices_to_style,   "bold",   file.path(temp_dir, "S1.xlsx"),   "1A iris sheet_name" )  # Reopen the Excel file and browse the sheet with the iris data # You should see some of the rows (where Petal.Width < 0.3) are in bold now browseURL(file.path(temp_dir, "S1.xlsx"))

title: Introduction to excelerate
text: vignette demonstrates use excelerate package create supplementary tables example datasets.
code: library(excelerate)  # Set up temporary directory to save the excel spreadsheets in temp_dir <- tempdir()

title: Introduction to excelerate
text: examples use built-datasets: iris, ChickWeight, ToothGrowth, CO2.
code: # Load example datasets datasets <- list(iris, ChickWeight, ToothGrowth, CO2) lapply(datasets, head) #> [[1]] #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa #>  #> [[2]] #>   weight Time Chick Diet #> 1     42    0     1    1 #> 2     51    2     1    1 #> 3     59    4     1    1 #> 4     64    6     1    1 #> 5     76    8     1    1 #> 6     93   10     1    1 #>  #> [[3]] #>    len supp dose #> 1  4.2   VC  0.5 #> 2 11.5   VC  0.5 #> 3  7.3   VC  0.5 #> 4  5.8   VC  0.5 #> 5  6.4   VC  0.5 #> 6 10.0   VC  0.5 #>  #> [[4]] #>   Plant   Type  Treatment conc uptake #> 1   Qn1 Quebec nonchilled   95   16.0 #> 2   Qn1 Quebec nonchilled  175   30.4 #> 3   Qn1 Quebec nonchilled  250   34.8 #> 4   Qn1 Quebec nonchilled  350   37.2 #> 5   Qn1 Quebec nonchilled  500   35.3 #> 6   Qn1 Quebec nonchilled  675   39.2

title: Introduction to excelerate
text: use append_meta() add comments columns dataframes description. metadata presented README sheet Excel file. append_meta() function requires results argument dataframe colname_descriptions argument named character vector names column names values descriptions.
code: iris_commented <- append_meta(   results = iris,   colname_descriptions = c(     "Sepal.Length" = "Length of the sepal in cm",     "Sepal.Width" = "Width of the sepal in cm",     "Petal.Length" = "Length of the petal in cm",     "Petal.Width" = "Width of the petal in cm",     "Species" = "Species of iris"   ) )  chickweight_commented <- append_meta(   results = ChickWeight,   colname_descriptions = c(     "weight" = "Weight of the chick in grams",     "Time" = "Time in days",     "Chick" = "Chick identifier",     "Diet" = "Diet type"   ) )  toothgrowth_commented <- append_meta(   results = ToothGrowth,   colname_descriptions = c(     "len" = "Tooth length in mm",     "supp" = "Supplement type (VC or OJ)",     "dose" = "Dose of the supplement in mg"   ) ) co2_commented <- append_meta(   results = CO2,   colname_descriptions = c(     "Plant" = "Identifier for the plant",     "Type" = "Type of plant (Quebec or Mississippi)",     "Treatment" = "Treatment type (nonchilled or chilled)",     "conc" = "Concentration of CO2 in uL/L",     "uptake" = "CO2 uptake in mg"   ) )

title: Introduction to excelerate
text: Next, demonstrate combine sheets single Excel file using sheet(), spreadsheet() excelerate() functions. example create two supplementary tables, containing multiple sheets metadata data example datasets. saved Excel files temporary directory names supplementary_table_1.xlsx supplementary_table_2.xlsx.
code: supplementary_table_1 <- spreadsheet(   title = "Results for iris and ChickWeight. 'title' from spreadsheet().",   path = file.path(temp_dir),   file = "",   sheet(     iris_commented,     "iris sheet_name",     "sheet_legend for the iris dataset."   ),   sheet(     chickweight_commented,     "ChickWeight sheet_name",     "sheet_legend for the ChickWeight dataset."   ) )  supplementary_table_2 <- spreadsheet(   title = "Results for toothgrowth and C02 R supplied datasets.",   path = file.path(temp_dir),   file = "",   sheet(     toothgrowth_commented,     "ToothGrowth sheet_name",     "sheet_legend for the ToothGrowth dataset."   ),   sheet(     co2_commented,     "CO2 sheet_name",     "sheet_legend for the CO2 dataset."   ) )  # Save supplementary tables as .xlsx to temp_dir excelerate(   supplementary_table_1,   supplementary_table_2 ) #> Excel file saved successfuly at: /tmp/Rtmp34tNYg/S1.xlsx #> Excel file saved successfuly at: /tmp/Rtmp34tNYg/S2.xlsx

title: Introduction to excelerate
text: Excel files saved temporary directory definied top script. can inspect files using following steps: List files temporary directory make sure created. Open Excel files directly R using browseURL().
code: # List all files in the temporary directory list.files(temp_dir, pattern = "\\.xlsx$", full.names = TRUE) #> [1] "/tmp/Rtmp34tNYg/S1.xlsx" "/tmp/Rtmp34tNYg/S2.xlsx"  # Open the files to inspect them # The file name has now appended "S1" and "S2" by default in excelerate() browseURL(file.path(temp_dir, "S1.xlsx")) browseURL(file.path(temp_dir, "S2.xlsx"))

what: Customise the prefix to sheet name, spreadsheet title and filenames
title: Introduction to excelerate
text: sheet_template must contain {n} (referring table number) {l} (referring sheet letter). spreadsheet_template must contain {n} (referring table number).
code: supplementary_table_1 <- spreadsheet(   title = "Results for iris and ChickWeight. 'title' from spreadsheet().",   path = file.path(temp_dir),   file = "iris ChickWeight",   sheet(     iris_commented,     "iris sheet_name",     "sheet_legend for the iris dataset."   ),   sheet(     chickweight_commented,     "ChickWeight sheet_name",     "sheet_legend for the ChickWeight dataset."   ) )  supplementary_table_2 <- spreadsheet(   title = "Results for toothgrowth and C02 R supplied datasets.",   path = file.path(temp_dir),   file = "",   sheet(     toothgrowth_commented,     "ToothGrowth sheet_name",     "sheet_legend for the ToothGrowth dataset."   ),   sheet(     co2_commented,     "CO2 sheet_name",     "sheet_legend for the CO2 dataset."   ) )  # Append "1_A_", "1_B_" to each sheet name # and "Supplementary Table 1" to the legend title and file name # by default any spaces in the file name will be converted to underscores excelerate(   supplementary_table_1,   supplementary_table_2,   sheet_template = "{n}_{l}_",   spreadsheet_template = "Supplementary Table {n}" ) #> Excel file saved successfuly at: /tmp/Rtmp34tNYg/Supplementary_Table_1_iris_ChickWeight.xlsx #> Excel file saved successfuly at: /tmp/Rtmp34tNYg/Supplementary_Table_2.xlsx  list.files(temp_dir, pattern = "\\.xlsx$", full.names = TRUE) #> [1] "/tmp/Rtmp34tNYg/S1.xlsx"                                     #> [2] "/tmp/Rtmp34tNYg/S2.xlsx"                                     #> [3] "/tmp/Rtmp34tNYg/Supplementary_Table_1_iris_ChickWeight.xlsx" #> [4] "/tmp/Rtmp34tNYg/Supplementary_Table_2.xlsx" browseURL(file.path(temp_dir, "Supplementary_Table_1_iris_ChickWeight.xlsx")) browseURL(file.path(temp_dir, "Supplementary_Table_2.xlsx"))

title: Introduction to excelerate
text: vignette demonstrated create supplementary tables using excelerate package R. viewed example datasets, attached metadata datasets, generated Excel spreadsheets multiple sheets. excelerate package simplifies process creating Supplementary Tables can often time consuming, manual task manuscript preparation.

what: Create Excel Spreadsheets for Supplementary Tables
title: Create Excel Spreadsheets for Supplementary Tables
text: excelerate package accelerates creation supplementary tables research papers. Data Frame Conversion: Easily insert supplementary results ordered, numbered sheets Excel spreadsheets. Metadata Integration: Include comprehensive metadata legends column descriptions README sheet. Numbered Supplementary Files: Automatically organises numbers sheets supplementary files easy reference. Efficient Workflow: Accelerates preparation standardised, publication-ready tables. makes excelerate invaluable tool researchers looking efficiently prepare tables meet journal specifications.

title: Create Excel Spreadsheets for Supplementary Tables
code: install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("ameliaes/excelerate") library(excelerate)

title: Create Excel Spreadsheets for Supplementary Tables
text: Use append_meta() add column descriptions data frame. function annotates data frame descriptions column, inserted table first sheet (“README” sheet) Excel spreadsheet.
code: # Create metadata for iris dataset results <- append_meta(     results = iris,     colname_descriptions = c(       "Sepal.Length" = "Length of the sepal in cm",       "Sepal.Width" = "Width of the sepal in cm",       "Petal.Length" = "Length of the petal in cm",       "Petal.Width" = "Width of the petal in cm",       "Species" = "Species of iris"     )   )

title: Create Excel Spreadsheets for Supplementary Tables
text: Use sheet(), spreadsheet() excelerate() functions create save tables. sheet() takes output append_meta() (ie. data frame column associated description explaining contents), name sheet (appears tabs Excel files) table legend sheet. spreadsheet() combines sheets together spreadsheet object. Taking main title legend, path file save Excel file. last argument contains sheet objects sheet(). excelerate() generates Excel file spreadsheet. creates README sheet title legend, sheet legends column descriptions sheet. default prefixes letter number Excel file name, title legend sheet name. example, code “S1” “S2” appended prefix file name title legend. “A1” “B1” appended sheet names supplementary_table1 (two sheets) “A2” appended sheet names supplementary_table2 (one sheet). See package vignette details customise .
code: sheet1 <- sheet(   results,   "Sheet name 1",   "Specific legends for each table can go here." )  sheet2 <- sheet(   sheet_2_dataframe,   "Sheet name 2",   "Sheet legend 2" )  sheet3 <- sheet(   sheet_3_dataframe,   "Sheet name 3",   "Sheet legend 3" ) # Create spreadsheet specifying tables for each sheet supplementary_table1 <- spreadsheet(   title = "This is space for a legend title describing generally the contents of the file.",   path = "path/to/save/results",   file = "example_file_name1",   sheet1,   sheet2 )  supplementary_table2 <- spreadsheet(   title = "Results from a fabulous analysis about something amazing",   path = "path/to/save/results",   file = "example_file_name2",   sheet3 ) excelerate(   supplementary_table1,   supplementary_table2 )

title: Create Excel Spreadsheets for Supplementary Tables
text: output Excel file multiple sheets. title specified spreadsheet(). sheet_legends, specified sheet(), sheet. meta data supplied append_meta(), sheet. remaining sheets data frames supplied sheet(). order sheet object supplied spreadsheet(). Example output package vignette Get Started:

code: results <- append_meta(   results = iris,   colname_descriptions = c(     "Sepal.Length" = "Length of the sepal in cm",     "Sepal.Width" = "Width of the sepal in cm",     "Petal.Length" = "Length of the petal in cm",     "Petal.Width" = "Width of the petal in cm",     "Species" = "Species of iris"   ) )  # Example to show column descriptions are stored as comments comment(results$Sepal.Length) #> [1] "Length of the sepal in cm"

what: Create and Save Excel Files for Supplementary Tables — excelerate
title: Create and Save Excel Files for Supplementary Tables — excelerate
text: function processes one spreadsheet objects (created spreadsheet()) produces Excel files according set customisable naming templates. applies user-specified patterns rename data sheets well update spreadsheet title file name.

title: Create and Save Excel Files for Supplementary Tables — excelerate
code: excelerate(..., sheet_template = "{n}{l} ", spreadsheet_template = "S{n}")

title: Create and Save Excel Files for Supplementary Tables — excelerate
text: ... One spreadsheet objects created spreadsheet(). sheet_template character string template used append prefix sheet_name supplied sheet(). default "{n}{l} ", : "{n}" replaced sheet sequence number. "{l}" replaced letter order Z. eg. Sheet names prefixed "A1 ", "B1 ", "C1 " etc. spreadsheet_template character string template append prefix spreadsheet title file (supplied spreadsheet()). default "S{n}", "{n}" replaced spreadsheet sequence number. eg. "S1_filename.xlsx" "S1. Legend title" README sheet. Note default spaces detected string converted underscores file name, aid file naming best practices.

title: Create and Save Excel Files for Supplementary Tables — excelerate
code: temp_dir <- tempdir()  results <- append_meta(   results = iris,   colname_descriptions = c(     "Sepal.Length" = "Length of the sepal in cm",     "Sepal.Width" = "Width of the sepal in cm",     "Petal.Length" = "Length of the petal in cm",     "Petal.Width" = "Width of the petal in cm",     "Species" = "Species of iris"   ) )  sheet1 <- sheet(results, "Sheet A", "Legend A") sheet2 <- sheet(results, "Sheet B", "Legend B")  sp <- spreadsheet(   sheet1, sheet2,   title = "Supplementary Table X",   path = tempdir(),   file = "example_file.xlsx" )  excelerate(sp) #> Excel file saved successfuly at: /tmp/Rtmp3W0Pdj/S1_example_file.xlsx  # List files in tmp dir to see file created list.files(temp_dir, pattern = "\\.xlsx$", full.names = TRUE) #> [1] "/tmp/Rtmp3W0Pdj/S1_example_file.xlsx"  # Clean up the temporary files unlink(file.path(temp_dir, "example.xlsx"))

title: Combine Sheets into a List for an Excel Spreadsheet — spreadsheet
text: ... Sheet objects created using sheet(). title character string legend title spreadsheet. path character string path save Excel files . Defaults current working directory. file character string file name save Excel file. spreadsheet. default spaces converted underscores.
